text: Is a formal I&T governance framework defined and approved by the governing body?
Are I&T governance roles and responsibilities clearly documented and communicated?
Is the committee structure (IT steering, etc.) in place and functioning effectively?
Are I&T governance decisions recorded and justified (minutes, resolutions)?
Is the I&T governance framework reviewed periodically to remain aligned with strategy?
Do key stakeholders participate in defining the I&T governance framework?
Are governance principles (accountability, transparency, fairness, etc.) explicitly defined?
Are regulatory and standards requirements taken into account in the I&T governance framework?
Are the expected benefits of I&T investments formalized in business cases?
Are benefit realization indicators (KPIs) defined and monitored regularly?
Are I&T benefits reviewed after go-live (post-implementation review)?
Are I&T investment priorities aligned with business strategy and value creation?
Are gaps between planned and realized benefits analyzed and documented?
Do decisions to continue, redirect, or stop a project consider benefit realization?
Is there a benefit governance structure (benefit owner, sponsor)?
Are stakeholders regularly informed about I&T benefit realization?
Is an I&T risk management policy defined, approved, and communicated?
Is an I&T risk register maintained and updated regularly?
Are I&T risks integrated into the enterprise-wide risk register?
Are I&T risk appetite and tolerance levels defined and approved by management?
Are regular reports on major I&T risks presented to governance bodies?
Are I&T risk treatment plans monitored and updated as conditions change?
Are cybersecurity and compliance risks explicitly covered in I&T risk management?
Are lessons learned from past incidents and crises integrated into the risk management framework?
Is a consolidated view of I&T resources (people, applications, infrastructure, data) available?
Are I&T resource capabilities and constraints considered in strategic decisions?
Are utilization and performance indicators for I&T resources monitored?
Are sourcing decisions (internal/external/cloud) governed and justified?
Are key skills required to support I&T activities identified and managed?
Does management arbitrate prioritization conflicts related to limited I&T resources?
Do critical projects and services receive the resources needed to meet commitments?
Are investment and divestment decisions regarding I&T resources documented and tracked?
Are key stakeholders for I&T topics clearly identified?
Are major I&T-related decisions communicated transparently to stakeholders?
Are regular reports on I&T performance, risks, and costs shared with management?
Are stakeholder expectations regarding I&T collected and taken into account?
Does I&T governance promote transparency on major incidents and their handling?
Are I&T financial reports reliable, complete, and understandable to decision-makers?
Are major changes in the I&T landscape (mergers, architecture changes) communicated in advance?
Are mechanisms in place to collect and handle stakeholder feedback on I&T performance?
Is an I&T management framework (policies, processes, structures) formally defined?
Are I&T policies approved by management and communicated to all teams?
Are I&T processes described, documented, and kept up to date?
Are indicators in place to measure the effectiveness of the I&T management system?
Are I&T management responsibilities (CIO, domain managers) clearly defined?
Is the I&T management system aligned with recognized frameworks (COBIT, ITIL, ISO)?
Are periodic reviews of the I&T management system performed and documented?
Do gaps identified during I&T management reviews lead to action plans?
Is a formal I&T strategy defined and approved by management?
Is the I&T strategy aligned with business strategy and enterprise objectives?
Does the I&T strategy cover digital transformation and innovation?
Is the I&T strategy communicated to business leaders and I&T teams?
Are strategic I&T action plans (roadmaps) defined with milestones and priorities?
Does management periodically review the I&T strategy in light of internal and external changes?
Are I&T-related risks and opportunities integrated into strategic thinking?
Do business stakeholders actively contribute to defining the I&T strategy?
Is an enterprise architecture defined covering processes, data, applications, and technologies?
Are urbanization or architecture reference models formalized and up to date?
Are I&T projects required to comply with defined architecture principles?
Is an application and data-flow landscape maintained?
Do acquisition or development decisions for new solutions take the target architecture into account?
Is enterprise architecture reviewed regularly to reflect changes in IT and the business?
Are gaps between current and target architecture identified and managed?
Do architecture boards decide on major choices (technologies, integration, cloud)?
Is a structured approach to managing I&T innovation in place?
Can innovation ideas be proposed by business users and internal teams?
Are criteria defined to evaluate and prioritize innovation initiatives?
Are experiments (POCs, pilots) framed with clear objectives and risk limits?
Are the results of innovation initiatives evaluated and capitalized on (successes, failures, lessons learned)?
Is I&T innovation aligned with enterprise strategic priorities?
Are resources (budget, time, skills) allocated to I&T innovation management?
Are risks related to innovations (technology, security, regulatory) systematically assessed?
Is a consolidated portfolio of I&T projects and services maintained?
Do I&T project requests follow a formal selection and prioritization process?
Are portfolio prioritization criteria (benefits, risks, costs, resources) defined?
Is the I&T portfolio reviewed regularly by management or a dedicated committee?
Are troubled projects identified and subject to formal decisions (correct, stop, redefine)?
Is the portfolio aligned with strategic objectives and organizational capabilities?
Is the workload of critical resources taken into account at portfolio level?
Is information on the portfolio status (progress, costs, risks) reliable and up to date?
Is an I&T budgeting process formalized and aligned with the corporate budget cycle?
Are I&T costs broken down by nature, service, project, and business unit?
Are budgets for I&T projects justified through business cases?
Are mechanisms in place to track actual project spend versus budget?
Are significant budget variances analyzed and explained?
Are I&T costs communicated in a way that business users can understand (showback/chargeback)?
Are cost optimization decisions (rationalization, cloud, outsourcing) managed?
Are financial risks related to I&T (overruns, contractual penalties) identified and monitored?
Is an I&T human resources management strategy defined (recruitment, retention, training)?
Are the key skills required to support I&T activities identified?
Is a skills development plan (training, certification) in place for I&T teams?
Are I&T job descriptions formalized and aligned with actual responsibilities?
Are individual and team performance assessed against clear objectives?
Is a knowledge transfer mechanism in place to limit dependency on key individuals?
Are turnover and the risk of losing critical skills monitored?
Are well-being, workload, and working conditions of I&T teams taken into account?
Are key business stakeholders identified for each I&T service?
Are formal contact points (business relationship managers, business counterparts) defined?
Are business needs and expectations regarding I&T services collected regularly?
Is user satisfaction with I&T services measured?
Are service commitments discussed and agreed with the business before implementation?
Are recurring frictions between business and I&T identified and addressed?
Are business units informed in advance of changes impacting services (maintenance, migrations)?
Do regular forums (follow-up committees, steering committees) exist with business departments?
Are I&T service catalogs defined and communicated to users?
Are service-level agreements (SLAs) defined for critical services?
Are service performance indicators (availability, response time, incidents) monitored?
Are SLAs reviewed periodically with the business to check their relevance?
Are deviations from SLAs analyzed and translated into improvement plans?
Are internal OLAs (Operational Level Agreements) defined to support the SLAs?
Do users have clear channels to report issues related to I&T services?
If applicable, is service cost allocation or billing transparent and understandable?
Is a policy for managing I&T suppliers and providers defined?
Are supplier selection criteria (quality, security, costs, compliance) formalized?
Do I&T contracts include clauses on service levels, security, and confidentiality?
Is supplier performance monitored through indicators and regular reviews?
Are supplier-related risks (dependency, location, security) identified and managed?
Are continuity or exit plans defined for critical suppliers?
Are regulatory obligations (e.g. GDPR) considered when managing suppliers?
Are disputes or contractual breaches handled through a formal process?
Is a quality policy covering I&T activities defined and communicated?
Do I&T processes include systematic quality controls (reviews, tests, validations)?
Are recurring non-conformities or defects analyzed to identify root causes?
Are continuous improvement plans implemented based on quality results?
Are quality requirements (standards, regulations) known and followed by I&T teams?
Do internal or external audits regularly evaluate I&T process quality?
Is the quality of project deliverables (specifications, development, tests) tracked and measured?
Are user feedback on I&T service quality taken into account in improvement plans?
Is an I&T risk management framework defined (method, roles, deliverables)?
Are I&T risks identified using a structured approach (workshops, analysis, mapping)?
Are I&T risks assessed in terms of likelihood and impact (qualitatively or quantitatively)?
Are I&T risk treatment plans (mitigate, transfer, accept) defined?
Is regular follow-up performed on I&T risks and related actions?
Are I&T risks integrated into the organizationâ€™s overall risk register?
Do significant incidents (outages, cyberattacks) lead to updates of I&T risks?
Are appetite and tolerance thresholds defined for major I&T risks?
Is an information security policy defined, approved, and communicated?
Are information security risks assessed regularly?
Are security measures (technical and organizational) implemented according to the risks?
Is user awareness of security (phishing, passwords, confidentiality) organized?
Are procedures for handling security incidents defined, tested, and known?
Is compliance with regulatory requirements (e.g. GDPR) assessed and monitored?
Are logical and physical access to critical systems controlled and reviewed regularly?
Are security tests (penetration tests, vulnerability scans) performed periodically?
Is a framework for managing the portfolio of I&T programs and projects defined?
Are programs and projects managed using a recognized methodology (waterfall, agile, hybrid)?
Are project roles (sponsor, project manager, business owner) clearly defined?
Are project risks, costs, timelines, and benefits monitored and reported regularly?
Do project stage gates result in formal go/no-go decisions?
Are dependencies between programs and projects identified and managed?
Are lessons learned from projects captured and shared?
Are projects evaluated after go-live against their initial objectives?
Are business needs collected using a structured approach (workshops, interviews, models)?
Are functional and non-functional requirements documented and validated by the business?
Are requirements prioritized based on value and constraints?
Are requirement changes managed through a formal change management process?
Are requirements traceable throughout their lifecycle (specifications, development, testing)?
Are regulatory, security, and performance constraints integrated from the requirements definition stage?
Are standard templates or models used for specifications to ensure consistency?
Are critical requirements reviewed jointly by business, I&T, and security teams?
Are solution options (buy, build, outsource, SaaS) systematically evaluated?
Do solution choices consider the target architecture and technical standards?
Are developments or configurations carried out following controlled development practices?
Are design and code reviews organized for solutions developed in-house?
Are reusable components (services, APIs, modules) favored to reduce redundancy?
Do solutions integrate security requirements from the design stage (security by design)?
Are solution acceptance criteria defined upfront with the business and operations?
Is technical and user documentation produced and approved before go-live?
Are service capacity and availability needs defined with the business?
Are infrastructure and application performance measured and monitored?
Are trend analyses performed to anticipate capacity needs?
Is architecture designed to ensure high availability where required?
Are the impacts of new solutions on capacity and performance assessed before deployment?
Are load and performance tests carried out for critical applications?
Are availability SLAs considered in technical solution design?
Do performance or capacity incidents lead to structural corrective actions?
Are the organizational impacts of projects (processes, roles, skills) analyzed?
Is a change management plan defined for projects that affect users?
Is communication on changes (objectives, schedule, impacts) organized and planned?
Is appropriate training planned for affected users?
Are resistances to change identified and addressed with targeted actions?
Are new processes and ways of working documented and integrated into internal reference frameworks?
Are business sponsors involved to promote change within their teams?
Are the effects of change (adoption, ownership, actual usage) evaluated after deployment?
Is an I&T change management process defined (normal, urgent, standard)?
Are changes recorded in a central tool or register?
Are change impacts and risks assessed before approval?
Does a change advisory board (CAB) rule on significant changes?
Do urgent changes follow a simplified but documented and post-approved process?
Are changes scheduled to minimize impact on production?
Are implemented changes documented and reflected in reference repositories (CMDB, documentation)?
Do failed changes or rollbacks result in analysis and preventive actions?
Are detailed deployment plans (technical and organizational) defined for go-lives?
Are environments (development, test, pre-production, production) clearly separated?
Are tests (functional, integration, performance, security) performed and approved before deployment?
Are production acceptance criteria defined and validated by operations and the business?
Are rollback plans prepared for each major go-live?
Is go-live formally authorized by the relevant stakeholders?
Are operations teams informed and prepared before each deployment?
Is post-go-live monitoring carried out to quickly detect incidents related to the change?
Is an I&T knowledge base (procedures, FAQs, solutions, articles) maintained?
Do resolved incidents and problems lead to the creation or update of knowledge articles?
Are I&T teams trained to use and feed the knowledge base?
Do end-users have access to a knowledge base for self-service?
Is critical knowledge identified and protected against loss (departure of key people)?
Are obsolete contents in the knowledge base regularly cleaned up or updated?
Are knowledge base usage and consultation indicators monitored?
Is the knowledge base integrated with support tools (ticketing, user portal)?
Is an inventory of I&T assets (hardware, software, data, licenses) maintained?
Are asset management responsibilities (owner, custodian) defined?
Are asset lifecycles (acquisition, operation, retirement) managed through defined procedures?
Are software licenses managed to avoid under-licensing and over-licensing?
Are critical assets protected with appropriate measures (physical and logical security)?
Are physical inventories periodically conducted to verify assets?
Are asset inventory data integrated into the CMDB or another central repository?
Are asset renewal or disposal decisions managed (costs, obsolescence, risks)?
Is a configuration management database (CMDB) used to record configuration items?
Are relationships between items (applications, servers, databases, networks) documented?
Are CMDB updates integrated with the change management process?
Are controls performed to verify consistency between the CMDB and the actual environment?
Is the CMDB used to analyze the impact of incidents and changes?
Are CMDB access rights managed to ensure data integrity?
Do critical configuration items receive particular attention (specific monitoring)?
Is the CMDB integrated with monitoring, ticketing, and inventory tools?
Is the I&T project management methodology defined and known (classic, agile, hybrid)?
Do projects have a documented project plan (scope, schedule, resources, budget)?
Are project risks identified, assessed, and monitored regularly?
Are scope or priority changes managed and approved formally?
Are steering indicators (progress, costs, quality) monitored and shared with stakeholders?
Are critical projects subject to independent reviews or enhanced controls?
Are formal project closures carried out (lessons learned, capitalization, archiving)?
Is project management maturity assessed and the subject of improvement plans?
Are daily I&T operations (backups, batch jobs, checks) planned and documented?
Are operations tasks performed according to standardized procedures?
Are operations logs (logs, reports) reviewed to detect anomalies and deviations?
Are scheduled changes coordinated with operations teams?
Do critical operations tasks have backup procedures (plan B)?
Are planned jobs (batches, nightly processes) monitored to ensure they run correctly?
Are access to administration and operations consoles controlled and logged?
Are operations capacities adequate for predictable peak loads?
Are service requests and incidents recorded in a ticketing tool?
Are incidents categorized and prioritized according to defined criteria?
Are incident resolution times monitored against service commitments?
Do standard service requests (e.g. account creation) follow predefined workflows?
Are users informed when their tickets are taken in charge and resolved?
Do recurring tickets lead to more structural corrective actions?
Is user satisfaction with support measured?
Are tickets properly documented to facilitate resolution and knowledge sharing?
Are recurring problems identified based on incident analysis?
Is a problem register used to track root causes and corrective actions?
Are root cause analyses (RCA) performed for major incidents?
Are workarounds documented and communicated to support teams?
Are corrective actions to eliminate problems planned and monitored?
Are problems prioritized according to their business impact?
Do security-related problems receive specific treatment with the relevant teams?
Are problem trends analyzed to identify weak areas in the information system?
Are business continuity and disaster recovery plans (BCP/DRP) defined for critical services?
Are business continuity requirements (RTO, RPO) formalized and approved?
Are backups performed, controlled, and tested regularly?
Are failover and recovery tests organized to verify the effectiveness of continuity arrangements?
Are disaster risks (fire, flood, major outage) considered in continuity planning?
Are crisis management procedures defined and known (crisis team, roles, communication)?
Do continuity test results lead to improvement plans?
Are continuity plans updated after major changes in the IT environment or organization?
Are security logs (authentication, access, events) collected and analyzed?
Does a security operations center (SOC) or equivalent monitor security events?
Are intrusion detection, anti-malware, and endpoint protection tools deployed?
Are procedures for managing security incidents (detection, response, communication) in place?
Are privileged accounts subject to specific controls (bastion, traceability)?
Are security patches applied under a defined patch management process?
Are remote accesses (VPN, supplier access) secured and monitored?
Are security incidents analyzed to implement preventive measures?
Are I&T controls embedded in critical business processes identified and documented?
Are data integrity, completeness, and confidentiality controls implemented?
Are application access controls defined according to the least-privilege principle?
Are automated application controls (validations, reconciliations) reviewed regularly?
Are critical manual controls documented and are responsible persons trained?
Do internal or external audits evaluate the effectiveness of business process controls?
Are control failures analyzed and corrected quickly?
Do business process changes include a review of associated controls?
Is a mechanism for monitoring I&T performance (dashboards, KPIs) in place?
Are I&T performance indicators aligned with business and strategic objectives?
Are I&T performance results shared with key stakeholders?
Are improvement actions defined based on I&T performance results?
Are I&T performance targets reviewed periodically to remain relevant?
Are I&T performance reports reliable and produced in time to support decision-making?
Is supplier performance included in the overall I&T performance monitoring?
Are I&T performance trends analyzed to anticipate deviations?
Is an I&T internal control framework defined (references, policies, responsibilities)?
Are key I&T controls (access, changes, continuity, security) identified?
Are periodic assessments of I&T internal control effectiveness carried out?
Do identified control weaknesses lead to remediation plans that are monitored?
Are responsibilities for I&T internal control clearly assigned (lines 1, 2, 3)?
Are I&T internal control assessment results shared with management and internal audit?
Are I&T controls adapted when significant changes occur in systems or processes?
Are external reference frameworks (e.g. SOX, ISO 27001) considered in the I&T internal control system?
Are regulatory and contractual requirements applicable to I&T identified and tracked?
Are I&T compliance responsibilities (legal, DPO, CISO, etc.) clearly established?
Are I&T compliance reviews or audits conducted regularly?
Do identified non-compliances result in tracked action plans?
Are regulatory changes monitored and integrated into I&T processes?
Is compliance with personal data protection requirements (e.g. GDPR) assessed?
Are I&T compliance reports communicated to authorities or other stakeholders when required?
Are compliance clauses included in and monitored through contracts with I&T suppliers?
